Dreamtime Minigame

From Peragro Tempus Wiki

Dreamtime is to be a minigame opened to "sleep"; allowing a significantly improved rate of Stamina regeneration. Because of the special relationship between sleep/dreaming and other activities it's important that such a mini-game be something special and interesting.

The current plan is to use a roguelike[1][2] game to simulate a dream-realm. The following document assumes this.

Entering Dreamtime

When a character chooses the "prone" position they will be presented with a button indicating that they will sleep. While being prone presents the best position-based regeneration rate for stamina and willpower, sleeping allows a character to gain bonus regeneration via performance in the mini-game.

Options

The only option for dreamtime is how "soundly" the character sleeps. The deeper their sleep the more space on the PT window is occupied by the Dreamtime screen, the less likely the character is to wake in response to environmental factors, and the greater their potential regeneration bonuses. The settings (from smallest window and most likely to be knocked out of Dreamtime) are;

Catnap one eighth PT window or less woken by any perceived movement within XX meters or the character's name being said within hearing
Light sleep one quarter the PT window woken by any perceived movement within (XX/2) meters or the character's name being said within hearing
Normal sleep one half the PT window woken by any perceived movement within (XX/4) meters.
Deep Sleep three quarters the PT window Woken upon suffering an attack.
Sleep of the Dead
Sleep of the Lotus Eaters 		Full PT window Woken upon death.

Leaving Dreamtime

The easiest way for a character to "wake up" is to close the Dreamtime window. This "kills" the current Dreamtime game-character, however.

Another way to leave Dreamtime is dream-character-death. In this event the player is presented with a notification of having "woken up" as they are ejected from Dreamtime.

Finally, obviously, meeting the events of the soundness the player has chosen will remove the character/player from dreamtime. This has a percent chance not to immediately kill the dreamtime persona equal to the % of the window occupied by the game. Should a character return to sleep without changing position after such an awakening they can be returned to their previous Dreamtime game.

Dreamtime Play

Generally, dreamtime should play as a normal session of a roguelike with a graphic interface [3]. Because of the limited playtime within PT the quest for the Amulet of Yendor becomes somewhat superfluous to other priorities. On the whole, Dreamtime will generally be a much "gentler" version than normal rouglikes.

Regeneration

Improved regeneration could be granted in one of two ways;

  1. by score.
  2. by purchased/discovered "power ups"

Death

As previously noted, having a Dreamtime character killed will eject the PT player from Dreamtime. This will be done without giving the opportunity to identify items possessed. Such items will remain in place for later characters to find, along with other potential results of the typical roguelike "bone file."


Future Complications

Shared Realms

If characters reach beyond a certain point in the Dreamtime they might enter an area (or areas) accessible by multiple dreamers. Perhaps quests for normal PT play could require reaching this point, or quests in the "waking world" could be given by another sleeper.

State Saving

As previously noted, some relics of previous play will remain in storage for later "dreams," including the standard Roguelike "bone file." Similarly, some frequently visited locales might become permanent areas the character can return to.
